item.title: Using network graph modeling to capture overarching thematic clusters in employee comments

item.description: A showcase on how to use network analysis to display the co-occurrence of topics in employee comments.

item.title: Can there be too much cognitive diversity in teams?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: The answer might be "yes", at least in the case of team collective intelligence, defined as a general ability of a team to work together across a wide array of tasks.

item.title: Estimating body height using an inventory?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k

item.title: NetLogo: Don‚Äôt tell me, show me
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: An example of how to get a better understanding of various complex phenomena through simulation in NetLogo, a free programmable multi-agent modelling environment.

item.title: Feedback can be a gift or a curse...
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: ...depending on where it directs your locus of attention.

item.title: If you are a leader, don't be afraid to be a nice one

item.title: Does agile pay off?

item.description: During my career, I have been part of several teams that have organized their work using some of the existing agile methodologies. For the most part, agile principles made good sense to me and subjectively seemed to work, so I had no reason to question their supposed benefits.

item.title: A showdown between the Big Five, Enneagram, MBTI, and astrology
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Who you got your money on? üòâ

item.title: Biases introduced by video backgrounds during video interviews
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Every tool used for employee selection introduces its own potential biases into the process. This holds true also for video interviews, which have become increasingly popular among recruiters in recent years.

item.title: Creating new candidate topic labels on the fly during topic analysis with GenAI

item.title: How should teams be designed to be creative and innovative?

item.description: Does a power-law distribution of performance, as opposed to a normal distribution, support the concept of strength-based development?

item.title: Does GenAI make me a better (more rational) thinker?

item.title: Evidence on the presence of gender bias in selection settings

item.title: Using NLP & LLM to combat 'tip-of-the-tongue' moments during onboarding
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: How to make onboarding experience a little bit smoother with the help of NLP and LLM.

item.title: Exploration vs. Exploitation trade-off in our calendars
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: As I was going through my calendar recently to check who I had already met during my onboarding at Sanofi, I realized that one way to look at the calendar is through the lens of the Exploration vs. Exploitation trade-off. What lessons can we take from this?

item.title: Harnessing Bayesian analysis for business process simulation
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: A demonstration of how the outputs of Bayesian analysis can be used to simulate business processes while preserving inherent uncertainties.

item.title: A plausible model of data-generating process eats ML algorithms for breakfast

item.description: An illustration of one of the lessons I took away from studying the use of meta-learners for causal inference.

item.title: Embedding R (or Python) ML models in Power BI dashboards
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: In my new job, we currently rely a lot on Power BI when presenting people-related insights to our stakeholders. Since I know Power BI quite superficially and we also want to share insights from more complex analyses with our stakeholders, I spent part of the weekend studying how to incorporate ML models created in R or Python into Power BI dashboards. I put my learnings in this blog post. It's definitely not rocket science, but it may still shorten the learning path for some of you who are in a similar situation.

item.title: Vocational interests don't seem so uninteresting after all
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Quite surprising (at least to me) findings on the validity of vocational interests for predicting a range of important work outcomes.

item.title: Induced centralities
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: A post about useful complement to common ONA centrality measures.

item.title: Searching & querying AIHR blog posts on People Analytics topics
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: I'm sharing a by-product of my learning about vector database search that may be useful to some of you who want to learn something new about People Analytics.

item.title: Using Bayesian shrinkage in reporting employee turnover
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: When you report turnover rates by team, do you take into account the size of individual teams, or do you take the turnover rate numbers as they are?

item.title: A bet on a new job
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Sharing a by-product of my search for a new full-time job.

item.title: Themes in Deloitte's Global Human Capital Trends between 2011 and 2023
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Reading the latest release of Deloitte Global HC Trends made me wonder what common themes this regular series has been covering throughout its 12 years long history.

item.title: Team-level predictors of innovation at work
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Team processes seem to beat team composition and structure when it comes to innovation at work.

item.title: Latent Class Analysis of responses from employee surveys

item.description: How listening to a podcast about conspiracies and disinformation inspired me to try out a "new" statistical tool popular among sociologists.

item.title: Another positive effect of mindfulness meditation on the horizon?

item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Bayesian networks seem to have some interesting properties that could make them useful for various people analytics use cases, but for some reason this is not the case.

item.description: How my own experience of exploring new job opportunities gave me the idea of how the company's career site could be easily improved using OpenAI's tools.

item.description: How did GPT-4 perform in the knowledge test of evidence-based HRM practices? Let's check it out.

item.description: How to use GPT and embeddings from OpenAI for identifying topics and related sentiments in employee feedback.

item.description: Comparison of Glassdoor ratings from current and former employees.

item.title: In need of multilevel correlations?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: A post about a great R package to reach for when you need to calculate correlations on nested data.

item.title: Consequences of time management in the workplace

item.description: Some interesting insights from a meta-analytic review of the consequences of time management behaviors in the workplace.

item.title: Interpretable machine learning with modelStudio
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: There's a new kid on the block in the R ecosystem that can help analysts understand the behavior of their ML models.

item.title: Ask your personality using GPT
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Can Generative AI like GPT meaningfully interpret personality profiles?

item.title: Effectiveness of interventions for encreasing employee engagement
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: What evidence do we have for the effectiveness of interventions for increasing employee engagement? Let's check it out.

item.title: Where do managers put on their rose-tinted glasses the most?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: In which areas are managers and leaders prone to overconfidence, and how can this overconfidence potentially impact team functioning? Let's check some data to address this question.

item.title: Estimating the impact of a new business app by piloting & method of difference-in-differences
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: What is the benefit of using the difference-in-differences method in combination with piloting a new business app, and how can this help estimate the app's effectiveness on key outcomes like time spent with prospects or closed deals?

item.title: Are there meeting ‚Äúyes-men‚Äù?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: One of our clients was struggling with meeting overload and wanted to know if the people who attend too many meetings are the kind of "yes-men" who just can't say no to meeting invites. You know the type - always saying "yes" and never protecting their precious time. What did they find?

item.title: Impact of employee satisfaction at work on a company's bottom line
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: While there is evidence supporting the connection between employee satisfaction and a company's bottom line, it's essential to determine whether higher satisfaction directly causes better performance. Is there some evidence for that? Let's check it out.

item.title: Excel + Python = Word Document
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Using combination of Excel and Python for semi-automatic Word document generation.

item.title: Employee outcomes & employees' job attitudes
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: What employee outcomes are predicted by what employees' job attitudes? Let's check it out.

item.title: Effectiveness of micro-breaks at work
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Quite satisfying news from a meta-analysis on the efficacy of micro-breaks for increasing well-being and performance in the workplace.

item.title: Not-so-hidden cost of working in an office
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Just a few data-backed thoughts on why many of us may often feel more distracted when working in an office.

item.title: Using ChatGPT to summarize and explore employee feedback?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: What's the potential use of tools like ChatGPT in analyzing open-ended feedback from employee engagement and satisfaction surveys? Let's take a look at the result of my little experiment in this area.

item.title: Where to look first when considering meeting reset?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Let's briefly discuss the potential benefits of focusing on optimizing large recurring meetings to save time in the workplace.

item.title: HRM value chain and structural equation modeling - Moneyball case
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: What's the link between the HRM value chain and structural equation modeling? Let‚Äôs check it out.

item.description: How to effectively combine information about the formal organizational structure of a company and the actual collaborative activities of its employees?

item.title: Span of control and collaboration data
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: How can collaboration data be used to determine the "optimal" scope of control?

item.title: Attaching numbers to best practices for instant messaging
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Slack and other instant messaging platforms can be both a blessing and a curse. Can we attach numbers to some of the recommendations on how to use them effectively? Let's take a look.

item.title: Always messaging
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Let's take a look at two concepts from computer science that can be used in the workplace to improve people's focus and productivity, and expose two methods for measuring their related behaviors when collaborating on instant messaging platforms.

item.title: Warning system for overloaded employees
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: What tools and/or signals can we use to identify employees at increased risk of overload? Let's take a look at some of the options we have in this regard.

item.title: Evaluation of the results of the evidence-based HRM knowledge test
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Have we made any progress in knowledge of evidence-based HRM practices in the last 20 years? Apparently not. But let's look at the details.

item.title: How to improve effectiveness of meetings?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: What suggestions do people have for improving the effectiveness of meetings? Let's check it out.

item.title: Why are meetings in/effective?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: If you are a regular organiser or attendee of meetings, you may be interested in what people think about the reasons why the meetings they attend are in/effective, as this can give you a better chance of contributing to making your meetings more effective and meaningful for you and others.

item.title: Signals of a good manager
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Do you think it's possible to find signals in collaboration (meta)data that someone is a good manager? Let's give it some thought.

item.title: Evidence-based HRM knowledge test
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Interested in testing your knowledge of evidence-based HRM practices? If so, click and get started.

item.title: Can you really unplug?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: With the Christmas holidays approaching, the following question is more relevant than ever, with the exception of the summer vacations: Can we really disconnect from work during the vacations? And what can collaboration data tell us about this?

item.title: One does not simply do a business without getting lost
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Breaking down one weekend association.

item.title: How to quickly navigate dashboard users to what they need to know?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Let's take a look at some tips and tricks to make dasboards more useful for their users.

item.title: Eisenhower matrix for meetings
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Meet the Eisenhower matrix for meetings ;)

item.title: Some resources on staff retention and downsizing
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Probably due to the current situation in the talent market, where many companies are laying people off and at the same time are worried about losing their key employees, a few people have contacted me in recent weeks asking for some tips on evidence-based approaches to dealing with retention and downsizing.

item.title: Evidence-based interventions that help reduce the gender pay gap
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Pay inequality between men and women is not only an ethical and legal issue for companies, but also a marketing issue - it can have a negative impact on their "employer brand" and attractiveness as an employer. This means that if companies want to attract and retain talented employees, they must be able to ensure that they treat men and women equally in this respect. Let's look at what the existing evidence tells us about what might help us with this.

item.title: It's perfectly normal not to be normal
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: And it definitely applies to the shape of the distribution of many HR metrics. Let's look at this in a little more detail.

item.title: A visual introduction to Bayesian belief updating
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Teacher: "Bayesian belief updating involves combining existing or prior beliefs with an assessment of the strength of new evidence." Student: "And could I please see this in action?"

item.title: Police cadet evaluation dataset
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: A "new" real-world dataset useful for training in people analytics.

item.title: Divide and... understand
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Finding the breakpoint when people start to score significantly higher/lower on a given criterion - the use case for the Conditional Inference Tree algorithm.

item.title: Timeboxing. Does it really work?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Checking with real-world collaboration data whether timeboxing has a protective function in terms of time available for focused work.

item.title: Multilevel modeling in people analytics
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Don't chase (statistical) ghosts and use multilevel models instead!

item.title: Collaboration and personality
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Personality is not fate, at least when it comes to the level of engagement in corporate communication and collaboration.

item.title: Hot spots of collaboration overload and collaboration bottlenecks and how to find them
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: One of the most useful insights that can be gleaned from collaboration data is where hot spots of potential collaboration overload and/or collaboration bottlenecks may exist in a company. Such insight can be especially valuable these days, when many companies are trying to fight the upcoming economic downturn by achieving more with less.

item.title: Are back-to-back meetings for good or bad?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: A short post about the practice of back-to-back meetings and how to determine when it's for bad and when it's rather for good.

item.title: The impact of the COVID pandemic on the popularity of people analytics
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Many people analytics professionals think that after the COVID pandemic, organizations are more willing to listen to their insights and recommendations. Can we find any empirical support for their hunch? Let's check it out with data provided by Google Trends and segmented regression analysis of interrupted time series.

item.title: People Analytics Challenge from Orgnostic: Plan for high growth
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: A brief summary of my participation in Orgnostic's People Analytics Challenge.

item.title: Visual statistical inference
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Visual statistical inference represents a valid alternative to standard statistical inference, and as a by-product it also helps with building intuition about the difference between signal and noise. Give it a try.

item.title: Standard vs. trend predictors
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: When modeling a phenomenon, one usually can't get by with just raw data but must use one's domain knowledge to select and transform the most relevant variables from raw data to be able to successfully grasp regularities in the domain of one's interest. Let's look at one simple example of such feature engineering from the domain of collaboration analytics.

item.title: Fighting meeting overload
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: One of the most effective ways to fight meeting overload is to better plan meetings in terms of the time we spend in them. Let's look at how data can tell us how much room for improvement we have in this area.

item.title: How do we perceive probability words?
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Have you ever wondered exactly how much chance of success people give a project when they say they believe in it? If so, then you may find this post useful, as it attempts to answer that question at least in part with data.

item.title: Hofstede's theory of cultural dimensions
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Cultural diversity brings both positive effects and some challenges. To deal with the latter, it is useful to have some kind of map to help people better navigate the cultural specificities of people from different societies. Hofstede's theory of cultural dimensions is useful for such a purpose. Let's check how dis/similar countries are on these cultural dimensions with a simple app that could help us better understand, manage and appreciate cultural differences a little better.

item.title: Makers' schedule and managers' schedule in collaboration data
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Many of us have probably already heard of Paul Graham's two types of schedules - one that meets the needs of makers and one that meets the needs of managers. But can these two types of schedules be found in any real collaborative data? Let's find out.

item.title: R Shiny app for LinkedIn connections analysis
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: An introduction of a simple R Shiny application for analysing LinkedIn connections.

item.title: Overview of predictors of voluntary employee turnover
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: An introduction of a simple R Shiny application to facilitate extraction and digestion of information from meta-analysis of predictors of voluntary employee turnover.

item.title: Modeling impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on people‚Äôs interest in work-life balance and well-being
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Illustration of Bayesian segmented regression analysis of interrupted time series data with a testing hypothesis about the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on increase in people's search interest in work-life balance and well-being.

item.title: HR analytika a odchodovost zamƒõstnanc≈Ø
item.dc:creator: Ludƒõk Stehl√≠k
item.description: Kter√© faktory p≈ôisp√≠vaj√≠ k odchodovosti zamƒõstnanc≈Ø a u kter√Ωch konkr√©tn√≠ch zamƒõstnanc≈Ø je zv√Ω≈°en√© riziko, ≈æe firmu bƒõhem nƒõkolika p≈ô√≠≈°t√≠ch mƒõs√≠c≈Ø opust√≠? Na tyto ot√°zky se ƒç√≠m d√°l t√≠m v√≠ce firem sna≈æ√≠ odpovƒõdƒõt pomoc√≠ anal√Ωzy dat o sv√Ωch vlastn√≠ch zamƒõstnanc√≠ch. V tomto ƒçl√°nku se prost≈ôednictv√≠m analytick√©ho n√°stroje R a vizualizaƒçn√≠ho n√°stroje Shiny pod√≠v√°me, jak m≈Ø≈æe b√Ωt tento druh HR analytick√©ho projektu pro firmy u≈æiteƒçn√Ω.

item.title: Moneyball v HR

item.description: P≈ôes popularitu t√©matu HR analytiky mezi HR profesion√°ly je st√°le relativnƒõ m√°lo spoleƒçnost√≠, kter√© HR analytiku re√°lnƒõ a systematicky vyu≈æ√≠vaj√≠. Jednou z mo≈æn√Ωch p≈ô√≠ƒçin je to, ≈æe tradiƒçn√≠ HR mnohdy postr√°d√° analytick√Ω mindset a nƒõkter√© z kompetenc√≠, kter√© jsou kl√≠ƒçov√© pro √∫spƒõ≈°nou realizaci HR analytick√Ωch projekt≈Ø. V takov√© situaci m≈Ø≈æe b√Ωt u≈æiteƒçn√© pod√≠vat se ve vƒõt≈°√≠m detailu na celkovou logiku i na konkr√©tn√≠ analytick√© kroky nƒõjak√©ho √∫spƒõ≈°n√©ho p≈ô√≠kladu vyu≈æit√≠ HR analytiky k optimalizaci nƒõkter√©ho z HR proces≈Ø s pozitivn√≠m dopadem na obchodn√≠ v√Ωsledky spoleƒçnosti. V tomto ƒçl√°nku se t√≠mto zp≈Øsobem pod√≠v√°me na zn√°m√Ω p≈ô√≠bƒõh oaklandsk√©ho baseballov√©ho t√Ωmu "√Åƒçek", jeho≈æ management pomƒõrnƒõ radik√°lnƒõ - a podle v≈°eho i √∫spƒõ≈°nƒõ - p≈ôehodnotil sv≈Øj dosavadn√≠ p≈ô√≠stup k v√Ωbƒõru nov√Ωch hr√°ƒç≈Ø na z√°kladƒõ v√Ωstup≈Ø statistick√© anal√Ωzy sabermetrick√Ωch dat o hern√≠m chov√°n√≠ hr√°ƒç≈Ø. Vyu≈æijeme p≈ôi tom volnƒõ dostupn√Ω statistick√Ω software R a ve≈ôejnƒõ dostupnou datab√°zi historick√Ωch √∫daj≈Ø o v√Ωsledc√≠ch v americk√© baseballov√© lize.
